review_title: Overall a good place to work, but low pay
job_title: Communications Specialist in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
I have great colleagues who care about the students. The benefits package is fantastic. The campus is absolutely gorgeous and you feel surrounded by nature. Overall I get a peaceful, laid-back vibe when I work on campus. It's pleasant to work here.

I think UCSC tried its best to support us during the pandemic. They might not have always hit the target, but it's obvious that they're trying hard.
cons:
The pay simply does not match what it takes to live in Santa Cruz and surrounding areas. I will not be able to make UCSC my long-term career because of this. There is no way I can ever afford to own even a modest home with the wages they pay me, and I don't anticipate that raises and promotions will ever make up for the discrepancy. This is the main reason I continue to look for another job.

Parking on campus is expensive and it's often hard to find a spot. I don't know if this will change now that remote work is probably going to be more common.

Also--and this will be a pro for some and a con for others-- if you're not a social justice enthusiast, you will hate this campus. The social justice vibe here is seriously next-level. If you work on campus, be prepared for protests of various types. The campus has only two entrances and protesters are adept at completely blocking traffic. Things can get ugly.

For the most par, IMO, the technology we use (CMS, for instance) is extremely outdated. It can get frustrating and embarrassing.

job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: They don't ask too much of students workers. Working at the library is relaxed, and working most places on campus allows for a more flexible schedule than working for a business off-campus.  My coworkers and supervisors are supportive, and Santa Cruz likes to offer career employment to student workers after they've graduated.
cons: They'll nickle and dime you. In 2018 they took away my 40 cent raise earned over two years (How cheap can they be!!!) because I didn't work at least 9 months in 2017.  The school year is only 8 and 1/2 months so unless you took summer classes now that raise is gone. And it won't come back as they've taken away raises for most student worker positions on campus. Back to minimum wage for many. They've tried to take away vacation and sick time from me in the past when I've switched full-time to part-time, and have done sneaky things surrounding my retirement package before too like refusing to allow me to opt out, transfer it until I've graduated, and charge more fees than the plan accrues interest. Keep on top of it otherwise UCSC will bleed you dry.

job_title: MSI Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Education learning views and vibes
cons: Not the best for resume diversification

job_title: Grader in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: there are no pros about this place
cons: everything from time, location, and attitude

job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: They are kind when they speak
cons: They can sometimes be unprofessional

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Ashland, OR
pros: There are some great students there.
cons: There's no respect for a humanities education.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Helpful coordinators and excellent faculty
cons: poor wages given the COL

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
beautiful campus
since you'll be working 3+ jobs, you gain a ton of experience in a short amount of time, making it easy to escape to greener pastures.
cons:
Unnecessary bureaucracy impedes your ability to do a good job.
Bullying.
Way overworked, everyone's working at least 3 jobs. Impossible to do a thorough job.
High turnover outpaces slow hiring.
Traditional and old-fashioned work culture. Innovative, younger workers don't stick around long. 
Low pay. Average benefits don't make up for it.
Neverending learning curve.
Extreme hierarchy. Lower level staff are not trusted, need approval from 5 different people to do pretty much anything and get blamed for virtually everything.
Hostile work environment. Everyone is stressed. 
Difficult co-workers. Everyone wants to be a leader and no one wants to actually collaborate.
Sick days get wasted on mental health days. Hoard them as much as you can because you'll need them. 
Ageism.

review_title: My first job ever as a Student Assistant 2 with UCSC Dining Services
job_title: Student Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The dining hall I worked at had an very friendly work environment. Full time staff, student leaders and managers were always willing to answer any questions that I had and were also willing to help out if i needed them. If you work hard, keep a positive attitude, and help others out, management will notice and you could be promoted to SA3 or SA4 in a few quarters. Overall, it was a great learning experience and highly recommend those who haven't had a job before college to start there.
cons: The major con for me was the fact that some student managers were terrible at their jobs. Like, how did they get promoted in the first place...and why are they still here? Hopefully you won't have to work with one of those student managers during your time with the dining halls (I personally worked with more awesome student managers than bad ones).

review_title: Tutoring Students Is A Great Skill and Passion of Mine, from Economics, Spanish, Calculus, Writing + More!!
job_title: Academic Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The Most Rewarding part was watching as my students of radically different personalities  become a collaborative team of  the top grade earners!   I have a very strong natural leadership ability, As a senior myself., schedule was perfect, and the extra money was great.
cons: Tensions can run high during finals, and it takes creativity to get a  room of loud students to sit and get focused .  Sometimes we have to stay late and work through tough situations, but I remain a true leader to the end of every session.  I never felt over worked, and went above an beyond company's expectation.

job_title: Student Sustainability Officer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I learned a lot about sustainability and I felt  great about my position because I was designing programs for residents and engaging with students to give them tips on how to live sustainably. The programs were team-based and it was fun to work with my peers. The training was easy and made to be fun with ice-breakers so that co-workers could get to know one another. Generally, it was a great working environment.
cons: The position required a lot of busy-work and paper-work and seemed to dominate the requirements of the job. This is unfortunate because for a part-time job on sustainability there should be an emphasis on teaching and learning, not necessarily on bureaucratic protocol. Oh well!

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Graduate School in general, and UCSC in particular allow you to study what you love, work independently, and set your own schedule. UCSC has strong resources for Astronomy (and in general, in the physical sciences) and the opportunities are wide ranging.
cons: Support, especially for people who are members of marginalized communities, is limited. Academia often thinks of itself as a meritocracy. UC Santa Cruz's Astronomy department does a good job on an individual level of forming a supportive and inclusive environment, but as an organization, lacks the structural features which would promote true diversity over apparent meritocracy.

job_title: IT Manager in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
Working in a redwood forest or near the beach is great.
All the Pros of working in Higher Ed
Great people to work with
Management is generally good. 
Great product (research and education)
Layoffs have happened, but are rare. 
Benefits are worse than they once were, but are better than other industries
Library borrowing privileges
cons:
This is for the field of IT only. 
The faculty look to IT as a place that spends outrageous amounts of money on staff and have cut it by more than 25%. Demand for our services only increases.
Sometimes difficult to stay up to date with technology. 
Altho improving, there is a legacy of lack of business and management processes. 
Pay is about 30% less than elsewhere. 
HR and Management seems unable to hold poor managers accountable

job_title: Programmer Analyst IV in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
- beautiful campus
- uni benefits (although this perk is dwindling)
- Zero accountability or expectations, if that's your thing
cons:
- get paid at least 40% less in base salary than 30 minutes north
- expect zero raises (or bonuses for that matter -- my ten year "bonus" was a stainless coffee mug made in China)
- Nothing gets done.   We're talking government level bureaucracy and everyone plays politics.
- Many in senior leadership have middled around in the system for decades and have no real work experience.

The type of person who works at UCSC in any tech role is the type of person who will happily wait three months for the hiring committee to make a decision, to take a huge pay cut and be bored for most of the day.  The bar is low.  If you have any ambition whatsoever, you should look elsewhere.

review_title: Student Worker at UC Santa Cruz
job_title: Office Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: For the summer, the Maintenance department can take on many workers at a higher rate of pay than the university normally can. They are fair when it comes to hiring and just when it comes to firing.
cons: Working within the university, especially when they are constantly undergoing strikes that have to do with a revocation of worker's rights, is difficult. I feel as if they do not give many employees, those who have worked here for years and who have been nothing but loyal, the respect they deserve (though they may seem to in their contract).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: UCSC is in a gorgeous location ,with many natural wonders. We are a research university, and we have top notch environmental programs for undergrads.
cons: We are one of the lowest-paid unit considering we're in the UC system, which makes it hard to live in this expensive county. Also, too many staff are alumni, and bring that old culture to their jobs and don't want to grow with the times.

job_title: Decline to State in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, wonderful community, incredible benefits package. This is an environment where, if you can find a department you mesh well with and work you enjoy you could quite easily make a career here until you retire.
cons: Incompetent management, low pay, bizarre politics. The variation in quality and competency in management varies so widely that it's sometimes difficult to keep in mind that it's one big organization. Many of the most infamous managers have been retained through the same sort of policy of staff-shuffling observed in the Catholic Church: Abusive managers are moved rather than disciplined or terminated.

review_title: One of the better places to work in Santa Cruz City proper
job_title: Administrative Assistant III  in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The best reason to work at UC Santa Cruz is living in Santa Cruz. Work environments lack traditional hierarchies and snotty attitudes found a more "affluent" universities or in private industry jobs. Personal issues, flex time needs are well-addressed there.
cons: Assuring everyone single person/ agenda is represented is often monotonous and time consuming. The language adjustment from may be hard for some coming from less liberal or less socially conscious backgrounds.

review_title: Wonderful experience that helped me develop my professional network and technical abilities.
job_title: Peer Advisor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Amazing supervisors and fantastic office relations. When I came into the office for the first time, I didn't know anyone within the school of engineering. After working there for two months I had grown to know almost every student and faculty within that department. I got to work with many different students and shaped my own development as an engineering student.
cons: I have no cons that I can sincerely list. I was always happy to go back into the office and to assist however I could.

job_title: Work Tech Crew Member in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I love working at the Stevenson Event Center at UC Santa Cruz because I go to school here and it is super convenent, it is a beautiful campus, and has dedicated students, friendly and motivating staff, diversity of events, and a wonderful small-town feel. I have become very good friends with everyone I work with including the rest of residential life staff around Stevenson College. My work hours are flexible, the office is a safe and comfortable place to be in, and the events that we work are always exciting!
cons: The only con is that parking on campus is limited (just like any other college). Good thing they make the bus system so easy to use!

review_title: It can be a great place to work, but it depends
job_title: IT Manager in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Pockets of amazing people. Working in the redwoods. Working in Higher Ed. Library borrowing privileges. Pockets of opportunity to do amazing work. You can have a good work/life balance, but you need to make sure you hold the line.
cons: Weak management teams outnumber the good ones. Executive class are professors, who like at all universities, have never had a real job and in general are poor leaders and worse managers. This causes whole departments and divisions to be toxic and malfunctioning. However, in pockets of good management, UCSC has a tradition and culture of innovation, research, service, kindness, and creativity.

review_title: Porter Resident Assistant: Your Management Does Not Care
job_title: Resident Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
- Pays for your food and housing
- Get's you in touch with a bunch of your peers and creates a really cool circle of friends
- Gives you experience both with students and with management
cons:
- The CRE staff (your direct supervisors) are not the best, and the level of support they give you is lackluster. They hold you to standards they do not keep.
- Residential programs can be fun but add a lot to your workload
- A huge time commitment and time management challenge

review_title: You can make it a great experience for yourself!
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
I like to teach, so it is wonderful for me to be able to teach college students.
The experience varies depending who is the professor you are assisting.  In my cases, I was given a lot of flexibility, so I put a lot of work and creativity into organizing my sections, had a great time and was rewarded with outstanding reviews from my students.
Classrooms include up-to-date media facilities, staff is always available to help if one has any questions.
cons: You are quite limited to the role that you have.  There are no career opportunities if you are a TA.  You need to move on to another institution and become a professor.

review_title: A wonderful place to work if you don't want to make much money.
job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: It's gorgeous, collaborative attitude is the norm, people are generally very friendly, decent pension plan (despite the worries about its future)
cons: Limited restaurant options, commuting by bike is difficult, salary is nowhere near market for majority of workers, city of Santa Cruz is barely affordable to live in, State of California is consistently broke and unwilling to fully fund the University... pay freezes, furloughs, etc.

review_title: UCSC ITS:  Laid back, disorganized, deeply underpaid
job_title: Programmer/Analyst in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
* Super laid back
* Few expectations 
* Stable - you have to kill someone to get fired
* Interesting work in some departments
* Good benefits.  3 weeks vacation to start.
cons:
* Deeply underpaid - you will be paid less than silicon valley and less than private sector, and less than the parking patrol that writes your UCSC parking ticket
* Declining resources - budget reductions mean you will work with no resources and might get laid off
* V. little career advancement
* ITS sometimes has a habit of promoting completely incompetent people
* Seniority matters more than talent, passion, or social-skills

review_title: Staff are poorly supported by faculty and overworked
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: You get to work with smart people, support education, work on a beautiful campus, and get decent benefits. In addition, the staff are hard-working and supportive of each other.
cons: The UC system and UCSC are run by faculty who in a lot of cases do not understand the reality of what it takes to make a seemingly simple task happen. They are cutting more and more staff positions while taking on more students and faculty. Meanwhile, the faculty don't have enough support because the staff are stretched so thinly.

review_title: Great Place for Extra Cash While Studying
job_title: Student Worker in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Flexible. Works with your student schedule. Management is generally laid back. College atmosphere so working with lots of young people. Opportunity to move into Shift Lead positions if you start as a freshman and work there for more than a year.
cons: Lots of people come and go. The technology is getting old. The dish room is generally pretty awful in that it's hot and has no ventilation. Customers are busy students so they generally look through you as if you're just a machine that's there to serve them without any sort of normal interaction. Minimum wage. Hard to get a reference from manager as they switch between dining halls constantly.

review_title: Research Scientist at UC Santa Cruz University Affiliated Research Center at NASA Ames
job_title: Research Scientist in Moffett Field, CA
pros:
Relatively good freedom to pursue independent research interests.
Great vacation and pension benefits. 
Work hours are reasonable. 
Commute is very convenient.
cons:
Projects subject to the whims of civil servants who manage the projects, who quite often make poor decisions.
No sense of urgency for completion of work or projects.
Objectives are not to get the real research work done, but to publish research papers so that it can be demonstrated to the public how the research funds are spent.

review_title: Bright colleagues, supportive and collegial work environment and clear mission and values communication
job_title: Associate Vice Chancellor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Extraordinarily beautiful setting, excellent benefits and employee support and interesting, mission-driven work. There is a great deal of potential for internal job movement and advancement, with extensive training and development opportunities.
cons: Long-term employees sometimes lack motivation, stifling new initiatives and creating an atmosphere that doesn't foster growth and change. The caste system that favors academic staff (faculty) at the expense of administrative staff can be difficult to navigate, but that problem isn't specific to UCSC.

job_title: PhD Candidate in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Location, natural beauty, awesome people, brilliant scientists.  This is a fun place to work and people are very supportive of a work/life balance.  Great place to commute by bicycle.
cons: Too many administrators with no real power.  Teaching is sub-par and most teachers do it as a side job and are actually researchers. The campus is far from any restaurants and shops. Some facilities are a bit lacking but you can always drive to another UC to perform your experiment.

review_title: Beautiful Campus, Interesting Projects, Tolerant Community but a Byzantine Maze with No Direction and Poor Management
job_title: Project Manager in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The people are typically cool and there seems to be job security. The pay is decent and there are good benefits. No one tracks your every move or micromanages you.
cons: They literally throw you in the deep end with no guidance or support. The management seems to be totally disconnected from reality of what they expect people to do. Serious inertia to change. No raises or step increase!!

review_title: Nice, supportive place to do research, albeit bureaucratic
job_title: Research Software Engineer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: UCSC is a supportive working environment with good resources, intelligent, compassionate, creative people and a beautiful campus. It also offers great benefits.
cons: The University is very bureaucratic, which can be frustrating. As it is an educational and research-based institute, it does not pay as well as similar positions in commercial industries. Campus can be a bit of a pain to access and park. Parking isn't included with employment. As a software engineer, my position is funded by grants, which is unpredictable.

review_title: perfect for a student, not so much any one else
job_title: Graphics Designer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: if you are a student they will work with your class and studying schedules. feel like not going to work because you have a test next morning? no problem... they are usually very flexible with your hours. if you work for the dining service you got free food, which is a nice bonus for a starving student :)
cons: not very exciting; low pay; working with other students, in the sense if you like to work in a more professional environment you might not like this place.... although, it does depend on the department

review_title: A nice place to go to grad school
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The forest, beach, and meadows are some of the most beautiful landscapes in CA. The physics department is a friendly and open place to work.
cons: Teaching assistant pay is relatively low compared to the typical cost of living in Santa Cruz. Housing  options on campus are limited and expensive. Frequent undergraduate student protests can be disruptive, and even when many of us are sympathetic with the message of the protesters, shutting down the campus can be annoying.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Flexible schedule accommodates family life; wouldn't be able to manage getting school-aged children to/from school otherwise.  Beautiful environment.  I enjoy my work.  Able to get funding to attend a few conferences, or get training.
cons: Unions.  Mediocre-to-intolerable co-workers at times, some here for decades.  I enjoy continual learning, and optimizing my workflow, but it's hard to do that when others are resistant to change.  Constant changes in management, who don't understand what I do.

review_title: About as is expected for a TA
job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Like most universities, being a teaching assistant is not a glamorous job.  However, if teaching is something you enjoy UCSC has some of the best and most creative students to work with.
cons: Being a great TA has very little upside to it.  Your advisor is uninterested in you being a good teaching assistant, and there are no benefits to doing a good job other than personal satisfaction and the appreciation of your students.

review_title: Student Worker? Not too bad(?). Full time? You're going to be walking on tight-ropes here.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Accepting of different individuals, somewhat diverse workplace.
cons:
A LOT OF RED TAPE. Very bureaucratic environment, and it is very apparent that upper management does not care very much if at all for the employees under them. So many rules that need to be followed that certain services become unavailable to people if they are missing a single document. If I didn't need to worry for my job I'd just let it slide under the table, but regulations and my bosses say otherwise.

There have been multiple instances where employees were let go due to "insufficient budget to pay for their salaries" yet the administrator's salaries keep on increasing... I know that this occurred at multiple locations across the UCSC system through both word of mouth and through personal experience.

An administrator literally had a conversation in front of me about how she was planning on firing all of student employees who worked there so that she can get a salary boost instead. And sure enough, it happened.

Also, superiors plagiarising their employees' work is commonplace here. And people getting fired out of nowhere. There's also a recurring theme of people being severely underpaid and forced to do multiple peoples' jobs or else they would be fired. You know this is bad when those very people gripe about this to you and from multiple individuals.

The total lack of communication between the departments (academic, administrative, and business) leads of a lot of inefficiency and again, red tape. It's pretty bad, even for a public institution.

Also, a lot of rules that are, quite frankly speaking, outdated and laughable. For instance, did you know that UCSC can be expanded AS LONG AS no part of campus is visible from the city? And people wonder why there's a diminishing number of jobs and opportunities on this campus, besides the PR fluff that is published all the time.

A good bit of corruption and nepotism happens here. I wish I were joking.

review_title: UC Santa Cruz is a great University providing great work opportunities for their students.
job_title: ITS FITC Student Consultant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Fair work, decent pay, and appropriate scheduling are all a part of UC Santa Cruz's working environment.
cons: Unfortunately due to the many students being hired, there are low hours, and little opportunities to work in research or any higher-end jobs. Many of the higher-end jobs are privileged to the graduate students, so recognition of the undergraduates is low. Funding is relatively high, but a lot of money is either misplaced or misused in terms of priorities by management.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The employees within Staff HR are very helpful, genuine and work well together. This makes for a comfortable and warm work environment in which people are very welcoming and friendly.  The staff work very hard but also enjoy occasional work lunches, parties, and birthday cakes.
cons: Student workers are generally given unimportant or banal tasks that don't allow them to fully learn about the work place and the interesting work that goes on at staff HR.

review_title: Too many Chiefs, not enough Indians...
job_title: Anonymous in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: It's a beautiful campus, and there are still a lot of wonderful people working there. I always enjoyed working with the students; they are still optimistic and full of Life. If you enjoy academia, you will find it here, in spades.
cons: The level of red tape and bureaucratic B.S. (that's NOT 'Bachelors of Science,' FYI!) that is involved when it comes to wages for the staff is ridiculous. When I started in 2001, there were 12 people in my unit, and one Vice Chancellor. When I left in 2012, there were 3 people in my unit, and SEVEN Vice Chancellors. (These are all 6-digit salaries, by the way.) The top-heavy management is incredibly blatant, and extremely expensive to maintain. They sent us a memo stating 'We have to lay of 'so many percent' of the custodial crew, so you'll have to clean your own office...'  But did the admin lose anyone? NO.  Of course not. They're the ones 'balancing the budget.'  I wouldn't say 'don't work there,' but I also can't recommend it. They have also figured out clever ways to cut the benefits of people who get hired now.  It's just not the place it used to be.  I would go so far as to say that I would NEVER send my children there, either. They have found all sorts of reasons to jack up all the student fees, while cutting important services. Community college and the State University system are still much better deals.

job_title: Facilities Student Worker in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: they have a flexible schedule and always make sure you have time for your school work. My bosses were very nice, understood that being a student is hectic and having to leave work on short notice is an inevitability
cons: minimum wage pay and potentially difficult tasks. No jobs were given without making it very clear how they were to be completed but some of the jobs could be monotonous and physically strenuous

review_title: An overall lovely experience, with a few slight issues.
job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The campus is absolutely stunning. Thick forest, families of deer, bobcat's and coyotes. The town of Santa Cruz is very friendly and charming and the ocean front is lovely. The work environment was friendly and usually supportive.
cons: Salary for teaching assistants is lower than at many universities. Some elements of disorganization within the company. There were many things I wished had been communicated to me earlier in my employment, to avoid surprises and rushed deadlines later on.

job_title: Research Staff in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: It is a university, which to me is an ideal place to work. You are surrounded by intelligent people so the environment is intellectually stimulating. Endless opportunities to learn, pursue research and teach. There were no lack of people interested in the commercial world, but unlike most companies it was perfectly acceptable to be disinterested in business.
cons: It is a university, which means the pay is not great for most employees. There is a lot of bureaucracy at many levels: lab/center, department school, campus, state-wide UC system. Important to have good relationship with well-respected faculty member.

review_title: Tutor (MSI Instructor) at Learning Support Services
job_title: MSI Instructor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
* Most UC Santa Cruz jobs are union, and those unions are managed well, and the students largely support said unions
* The interview to get a tutor job is very low stress as they give you the questions, give you 15 minutes to think about them, and then ask them to you (although you do have to prepare an example session, so while you know what to expect, it's not a cakewalk and requires some prior preparation, which imho is a good thing)
* Tutors are the highest paid student employees, usually earning upwards of $20/hour
* Tutoring is an excellent opportunity to get close with a professor you may want a letter of recommendation from 
* Training for tutors is well-done, albeit a little bit annoying as it takes the form of a two-unit course and is if anything a little bit too thorough (also when I took that course several male STEM students once made a group project centered around a really sexist concept and the professors didn't point anything out until several female students spoke up about being uncomfortable and calling them out)
cons:
UC Santa Cruz treats its (unionized) tutors like myself well, however, it does not treat their low-income workers well, unionized or otherwise. If you're a student looking for a job on-campus, there are few cons to tutoring, but I have heard on the grapevine that dining hall workers, especially non-student workers, are not respected and that injuries have occurred due to understaffing leading to dangerous conditions.

One con of tutoring is that I was only paid for up to 15 minutes a week of preparation time (ie, a quarter of my hourly salary). This is ridiculous because a good tutoring session will require at least a half hour of preparation. If you team up with other tutors to prepare material, it's more reasonable, but if you are the only tutor for the class and you genuinely care about your students' success, you will probably end up doing unpaid labor in order to prepare for your sessions (making sample questions, etc).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Beautiful city, supportive coworkers, Excellent benefits.
cons: Staff have no room for upward mobility, near impossible to get re-classified even if they add extra job duties, every boss I had there told me the only way to "be promoted" was to look for a new position which is never what I wanted to do. I deserved to have gotten a raise, re-class, and real promotion after 8 years managing program.

job_title: GIS Technician in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I specifically work for the GIS Lab on the campus aka Center for Interspatial Research (CISR). The start up is small and takes projects and contracts from university, public, and private clientele. It's an exciting work environment where field data collection and programming really come together.
cons: There aren't really any bad parts of the job except for the fact that not enough student interns are working for the program.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Castro Valley, CA
pros:
Great chance for students to gain work experience.
Students who return for multiple seasons may have the opportunity to manage an office and gain leadership experience.
Frequent contact and communication with senior staff.
cons:
Training is not very hands on. 
Due to the seasonal nature of this job, most student employees are hired all at once with no experience in this role or a similar role.

job_title: Teaching Assistant & Graduate Student in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: First, yes I completed my PhD.  The campus is as everyone says beyond beautiful.  The buildings are nice.  The walk between buildings is amazing.  There are good resources on campus as far as research goes.  Acting as a Teaching Assistant can be draining on time but no one said it was going to be easy.
cons:
I am not a member of the LGBT community, but the campus does pay a lot of lip service to said community.  Which is good in it own way.  But actual action would be ever so much better.  I have known more than one person who has been discriminated against and it has been shrugged shoulders from administration and a trip to the counselor who says file a complaint.

A PI should be granted a good deal of freedom to run their lab as they see fit.  But that said, grad students without a home in a lab because of a cantankerous PI shouldn't be sidelined.  The departments I have seen treat the students that don't find a good match instantly with a PI as extraneous flotsam that should just float away.

I have also noted serous academic miss deeds by some faculty.  The research data gets fudged a bit, a data point dropped here or a control run slightly off there.  Students should also be holding their PI's to the mark.  But when the PI's hold all the cards and management doesn't act like the students have any value...  No one is going to come forward.  The trouble is it isn't egregious it just teaches people that cutting corners is ok.

This is a big one!  The cost of living is absolutely sky high in this area.  You are going to rent a one room studio for over half your monthly salary.  Because of the poor road layout you spend 20-40 min just getting off campus to get home, that is if you drive.  Parking is absolutely outrageously expensive too.  OK, so you take the bus, it is free after all.  But NO!  You can't.  You absolutely can not take the bus.  Why?  Because they are full and full for hours.  Wait at the bus stop at 8pm when you have been in lab since 9 am good luck.  You are going to stand there till 11 pm on some nights.  So you get home at 11 pm you don't have time to cook!  So you ether go out to eat or starve.  There is one other option.  Live on campus in family student housing...  Which is ok.  But not an option everyone likes as there are kids.  Yes they do scream at 7 am in the morning...  Which is ok if you don't mind a neighbor could be doing the same thing off campus.  Long story short the housing there is HORIBLE!  Far to expensive, and getting to it is way WAY to much work.  If you go to grad school you expect to spend 60-70 hours working.  When you spend 20 hours a week commuting when you live locally!  You are not going to be able to pull it off and come out achieving the work you want.  I would rather work 90 hours and not have to commute as much.

review_title: Working with Drupal for Fun and Profit
job_title: Web Developer Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Flexible hours, not much challenge to the job, very little oversight,  lots of experimenting and learning Drupal even though I had pretty much no coding experience.
cons: Working in a cubicle in the basement with only 3 people in a huge room is a pretty depressing work environment, made worse so than the two days a week where you work completely alone.  Good thing theres lots of things do to on the internet

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Easy Going, low stress hands on job. Great people to work with (students and supervisors), and due to the small  working crews, the crews get to know each other very well. Working over in summer in beautiful UCSC is always a pro.
cons: Even for students, the pay is quite low for the work being completed, borderline minimum wage as the supervisors assume the people working are only there for a short period.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The campus is gorgeous, the physics department is very highly ranked, people are generally very friendly. Lots of nature-related activities to do around town, from water sports to hiking & biking. Music and art scene here are thriving.
cons: Cost of living is absurdly high, and it is a pretty transient town as a result. Pay as a graduate student is not as much as I would like it to be. If you are extremely driven and used to fast-paced work environments, you may not enjoy the setting here

review_title: Generally a nice place to work.
job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
It's one of the most beautiful campus you can find in US.
Some world famous / top tier researchers/professors to work with. 
UCSC is still a young campus within UC system. Huge room to grow.
cons: The salary is relatively low compared with other public universities due to the State-wide budget cut. Losing some of its best professors.

review_title: Not a bad part time job
job_title: Sever in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Some of the pros have to be a good resume builder, works around your classes. This is a job for a full time student. The food is good and the jobs are not that hard.
cons: There can be a lot of pressure put on you from the fast environment of catering! I would avoid this if you like working in a more relaxing laid back kind of way.

job_title: Research Fellow in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: This a unique place to do the world class research. Very encouraged environment, very high level of research stuff. Good equipment and very good technical support. Helpful support from undergraduate students.
cons: The salary can be higher. Significant part of researchers is on short-term (usually one year) contract. There is a change in the retirement scheme, it can worsen the benefits.

review_title: A positive and collaborative work place.
job_title: Resident Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Very considerate and understanding superiors who want to see you grow and excel. The community is generally pleasant and the campus itself is beautiful.
cons: The secluded nature of the campus makes it difficult for those without a vehicle to get around. Public transportation is available but very inconsistent, especially on the weekends.

job_title: Teaching Assistant, College Or University in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Learning while working, interaction with students, flexibility, interaction with professors and faculty, large amount of autonomy in preparing lectures and problem sets
cons: Large class sizes and large expectations for section and office hours preparation. Classes are tough and TAs are not given much of a background on the material so sometimes have to work twice as hard as the undergrads just to keep up.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: There are some good faculty here and generally the department has been responsive to equipment needs.  My department is pretty cohesive with a lot of collaboration between labs.  Money is tight, though, with federal funding so low.
cons: This is very much a student driven campus.  There are limited food options and the campus is closed down during the student holidays even though work goes on for the rest of us.  Parking is expensive as is housing in the area.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant work is what it is
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The demands are as reasonable as can be expected. Beautiful surroundings help. The community is relatively mild in comparison to other locations making it a less stressful place to work.
cons: The cost to live on campus is unreasonable on the graduate research assistant salary. There is always a competition for office/lab space, even though it is "guaranteed" it is not necessarily delivered. Administration will slip rules in that disproportionately affect graduate students  taking advantage of the limited organization within certain departments

review_title: Insight into being a graduate teaching assistant!
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Somewhat flexible hours.  Provides tuition reimbursement.
cons: A lot of work for little pay.  Grading undergrads can be very time consuming.  Some students difficult to manage, but that is true in any teaching setting.

review_title: Incredible Wealth of Knowledge and stimulating Environment
job_title: Junior Specialist in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
Creative and open work environment, where driven individuals can excel and grow considerably.

The bar is set high for your success and there is a competitive atmosphere (at least in our lab).

The people you work with are all quite sharp and push you to do better work.
cons:
A very Isolating environment, cooped up in a lab for 12 hours a day 6 days a week takes a special type of person.

The monotony can be endless and is many times rewarded with failure.

job_title: MSI Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I loved this job.  Great way to master material and practice presenting in front of groups.  Also a great way to network with other high performing students and meet professors.  If you enjoy teaching/tutoring - this is a great way to get paid by the school to do it.  Looks good on a resume too!
cons: The class can be a little bit of a burden - but I did find it helpful and at least you get a little credit.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
Most professors give you freedom to think in your own way.
The salary is not bad for a TA position especially in bay area, you might not be able to rent an apartment but it is enough to afford good student life.
cons: On campus housing is really expensive. Santa Cruz is in general expensive so this place is not advisable for students who are out of state masters (and don't have funding source) and have a family or single PhDs who are not funded.

review_title: Great work-life balance, but difficult for ambitious employees
job_title: ITS Manager in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: True work-life balance, great mission, great benefits including a pension.  Great place to work if you live in Santa Cruz.
cons: Little accountability, staff don't have huge incentive to work hard or be innovative.  Very risk-averse culture in general.  Difficult to get a raise.

review_title: Lovely ladies and a lovely work environment
job_title: Mathematics Department Office Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: While the University has issues of its own, I was happy to find that working for the math department was incredibly pleasant and supportive. The women who work there are kind, compassionate, and open. They supported my needs as a student and employee.
cons: The university pays very little for the work its students do. This is a larger issue of the university not providing students with basic needs such as a livable wage.

job_title: Student Supervisor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Great learning opportunity for developing leadership, time management, task delegation, and teamwork skills, along with the ability to work under pressure.
cons: Mandatory 20hrs/week was invasive into my studies and hard to manage along with classes.

review_title: great place to be a grad student
job_title: Graduate Student in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: engineering department helps fund most students through grants, research positions, and teaching assistant positions.  I haven't had to pay any tuition as a masters student. and get free health insureance through the university.  Great professors and opportunity to work on progressive research projects.  good connections with companies in silicon valley (just over the hill).
cons: Some required classes dont relate to my research.  putting in a lot of hours with classes, research, and teahing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: It is an emerging research institution that is creative but still has growing pains.
cons: Many of the faculty and students on campus need to get pass racism. Of course, this extends from a significant degree of racism in the Santa Cruz community. This condition has slowly improved over the years but still has quite a road to travel.

review_title: Great place to work, but budget issues and history of stagnant compensation and benefits are starting to outweigh pluses
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Beautiful place, nice people, some flexibility with work schedules and hours.
cons: A lot of work, no merit increases, no cost of living increases.  Frequent management changes, limited opportunity or time for advancement or professional development.

review_title: Working at UCSC provided a positive working environment.
job_title: Program Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: UCSC, Cal Teach program was a positive environment. It fostered creativity while maintaing realistic program goals. I was given the opportunity to learn new programs and given the opportunity to apply them to the program I was working in.
cons: I did not have any challenges in this department.

job_title: Dining Hall Worker in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
Free food
Consistent Work
On campus

The main benefit is that this place is great for meeting other college students. It also allows you to have something on your resume for when you graduate.
cons:
Low pay (except for the top)
Incompetent managers

Sometimes there will be new rules that don't make any sense but you have to follow them. Every manager has a different set of rules that they adhere to. You must learn a different job for each manager.

job_title: Academic Coordinator in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: People are very intelligent and passionate. The students are nice. The campus is interesting. Very good family feel within each college's administration.
cons: The university is VERY bureaucratic, sometimes inefficient. Sooo many outdated systems. The decentralized nature of the campus causes many problems for staff trying to get stuff done, especially when politics come into play. Parking is terrible and very expensive; housing is almost impossible to find.

review_title: Great place to be a PhD graduate student
job_title: PhD Candidate in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The best thing about UCSC is the great community and environment here. It's laid back, but learning is always a priority. Also, the campus is totally beautiful.
cons: The school is suffering from a lack of funding, which affects both the grad students and the undergrads. I think that the salary for teaching assistants should be a lot higher to make up for the very high cost of living in the area.

job_title: Graduate Student Instructor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The best things about UCSC are the professors and the students and the intellectual freedom that is usually afforded by the climate at UCSC.
cons: The bay area is very expensive and UCSC pays very little.  The education system continuously is cutting budgets so now undergrads are taking over positions they should be paying grad students for and lecturers to do the work of tenured faculty.  Class sizes continually increase.  Not a reliable employer.

job_title: Budget Analyst in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Nice people, beautiful campus, meaningful work.
cons: No possibility of promotion; budget cuts resulting in five pay cuts to already low salaries over the past five years; pensions on the chopping block now (start to read deal-breaker).

job_title: Astronomer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Security in your job and freedom to research any where opportunity arises.  The major hindrance (a former Asc. Dir. of the Business Office) is not longer holding things back.
cons: Salary is outpaced by industry and the benefits for new employees doesn't make up for it.

job_title: Grad Student in San Jose, CA
pros: UC Santa Cruz offers a great opportunity for grad students to design and teach their own courses.
cons: Faculty are overstretched with teaching, research and administrative responsibilities.  Professionalization and development of graduate students is highly uneven and largely dependent on motivated and caring faculty to mentor.

job_title: Project Policy Analyst in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
- Stable work environment.
- New location in Scotts Valley for Administrative units. 
- Pretty good pay, medical, dental, vision, retirement plan.
- It's great to work with students. They are all so brilliant and inspiring!
cons:
- All of the pros depend on what unit you are in. 
- Retirement plan has degraded for new hires. I've heard that the optional 401k is now a better choice.
- Parking if you work on campus is very expensive.

job_title: Forest Ecology Research Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: UCSC has a lot of really great opportunities for students to get involved with research on campus and get paid. Working with Prof. Greg Gilbert was an amazing experience. I learned so much and it gave me a chance to make some money and work in my field while I was in school.
cons: The pay for student employees is not super high, but the experience and resume building makes it worthwhile.

job_title: Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Very decent pay, coworkers are friendly, and supervisors are generally hands off. You also get to set your own schedule, which makes it ideal for conforming to an academic schedule.
cons: Lack of communication with superiors makes it difficult to assess one's own performance, however they are available if you need them. Generally the pleasure derived from this job depends on one's students, which can have drastically different personalities and work ethics.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Competitive research groups for their small size. Beautiful campus and rather laid back atmosphere. The campus housing is a great environment to have a family and raise children in.
cons: Not many options for course work, especially good ones. Job fairs and social events are rather sparse and you would likely have to drive to San Jose or San Francisco for such opportunities. Low compensation (as expected for a graduate student).

job_title: Senior Maintenance Specialist in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
-Easy work, taught primarily by other students
-Extremely flexible to a student schedule that is consistently changing
-Relaxed work culture that emphasizes worker satisfaction and well-being
cons:
-Extremely routine work that can get tedious after a few months of work
-The pay-grade is low, but this is to be expected with this type of work

job_title: Circulation Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: -Very relaxed atmosphere, friendly staff, mostly slow work pace. If there are no patrons, nothing to check-in, and no reserves to shelve, you are allowed to surf the web on the computer.
cons: -Could get boring when there are no patrons and nothing to check-in, but this is a very minor criticism directed at the nature of the job duties and not of the staff or the workplace

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I really enjoyed my colleagues which were some of the best minds in the field. There were also a number of interesting courses available to teach.
cons: There was high bureaucratic overhead and lots of red-tape to get through to get anything done. It also led to some confusion over things like health care coverage and classroom availability. I assume this is common with any public university.

job_title: IT Support in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Resnet was a great introduction to desktop/laptop support, working with students and for students you are able to employ a variety of repairs to a plethora orfdifferent problems
cons: Very *cliquish* environment, though everyone would be friendly it was not uncommon to get singled out if you were not in the "in" group.

job_title: Community Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Leadership skills, Event Planning Experience, Networking abilities
cons: Duty/Documentations were the least favorite thing that I had to do during my time there. However, it is necessary and part of the job. Sometimes people reacted negatively to your position, but you learned how to communicate with difficult people, which was extremely valuable.

review_title: Like teaching, don't like the situation.
job_title: Lecturer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Students are amazing. Beautiful campus. I got to design my own class.
cons: No upside potential, low pay, no benefits at all. I'm not part of an intellectual community. No one even talked to me for three months.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The academic culture of UCSC is more collaborative than at other similarly ranked universities. For this reason, grad students are generally happier and receive better advising. Also, the research impact is very high. Finally, Santa Cruz is a great place to live.
cons: Inadequate job placement for graduates. The job fairs at UC Berkeley and Stanford are far better than the fairs at UCSC.

review_title: Research Associate position - great entry level experience
job_title: Research Associate in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
- Very friendly work environment
- Great benefits and PTO
- Opportunity to learn many techniques and contribute to the direction of the lab
cons:
- Very unpredictable schedule
- A lot is expected of you and often you will have many different types of tasks to juggle in a given day

review_title: Best place I have ever worked.
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: mostly relaxed atmosphere, beautiful setting, friendly professional co workers
cons: Most managers are friendly, but incompetent.  Much needs to  be done at UCSC to train managers, I think most of them should not be in the jobs they are in.

job_title: Lab Consultant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Able to multitask while monitoring lab means lab techs can work on homework and chat with friends while being paid.
cons: It was often difficult to find subs when needing to miss work, but missing without a sub is completely unacceptable.

job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Culture, Work-life balance, full medical dental and vision benefits if your appointment is full time, paid time off, beautiful scenery, and a place on campus that sells beer.
cons: Constant micromanagement, upper management with no experience in the fields in which they supervise their employees.  No promotion prospects unless you take another job on campus, or leave and then come back.

job_title: Housing Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: As a full time student, UCSC was great at acknowledging the need for work schedule flexibility during midterms, finals, etc. The staff was great and happy to mentor students.
cons: I was paid $9/hour when minimum wage was $8.25. Not sure if they increased pay based on an increase in minimum wage. The pay period for students was once a month which was difficult to manage.

job_title: in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Beautiful, liberal area with a mix off ocean and mountains. Some interesting programming but this has dwindled over the recession.
cons: You are working for a big system - there is a large disconnect from top administration to staff and admin staff unless nepotism interests you.

review_title: Stressful Management, Must Work In Office.
job_title: Video Producer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: good pay and benefits. Monthly birthday 'parties'.
cons: Funding may end at any moment without notice, Poor management. They are more concerned that you work exactly 8 hours a day than the quality of work, and rarely offer encouragement or positive advice. No remote working, stringent work policies.

job_title: Lecturer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The students were great! I loved working with students. The students are caring and intelligent and ask great questions and really want to learn. They are a joy to work with and teach (that's the main reason I liked the job - I loved working with the students). I felt like I was really impacting people's lives for the better, and got lots of engagement from students and positive feedback. It felt like I was really helping them in their educational journey, which aligns with my career and life goals.
cons: Admin. can verge on unfriendly, chaotic and disorganized department. You can be asked to teach classes VERY last minute (2 days to a week prior) so you have very little time to prepare. There is a lot of work outside the lecture hours for very little pay. It is very "hands off" so they won't help you if it's your first year (won't tell you which textbooks the department uses, or what is actually supposed to be taught/covered in the course). They tell you to "teach whatever you want", try to get the lecturers to take the responsibility when there's a strike or some kind of discord with students, instead of issuing a department-wide policy (such as students asking for no-harm final during protests). A big issue was giving false reasons that are against union contact for why they are paying a lower salary than they originally quoted (mislead about it; when the union rep looked at the communications, the rep said he was "floored" by it). The big one was they said they didn't want me to make more money than a particular person based on their personal preference (not university or department rules) even though I had the mandated qualifications and the very good teaching reviews. There is little to no room for promotion because a part-time lecturer is an Adjunct (although they don't use that term, it's effectively what it is). You are not guaranteed full-time courses or even any courses from term to term, and could be given courses at the very last minute. I believe you can get a small raise eery 4-6 years, but was told that unless it's stated in your employment offer they can try to take away the 4-year raise. You do not get certain union rights until you teach 18 terms which is about 6 years. It's such a low wage that is it unlivable and you will not be able to afford housing, either in the area, or within an hour commute. If they do not give you more than 50% course load you will not get benefits either.

review_title: UCSC is a great place to work! The staff are very friendly and do their best to help students excel.
job_title: Student Worker in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I love working at UCSC! My job at Admissions has been great! Amazing and hardworking people. There's always people to help you out and he staff are all very supportive of one another.
cons: Sometimes projects get lost in the approval process because of staff hierarchies.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Beautiful campus, amazing memories, helping students is always satisfactory. GSR salary is good but housing in the area is very expensive, so it barely covers expenses. TAships pay similar but don't cover non-resident tuition for grad students - so beware.
cons: Usual frictions with some professors out of touch with TA workload in courses. TAships should cover non-resident tuition for grad students.

job_title: Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
- I was research, so pay wasn't great, but you did get academic credits which was nice
- My professor was great, so the experience was great
- Good school for research in general, so there was a lot of motivation to keep doing experiments
cons:
None that I can realistically put on paper
Not a lot of upward mobility, but seriously, what do you expect?

job_title: Resident Assistant in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: inclusive campus community that was welcoming to new perspectives. Had capacity to make genuine impact on residents' lives.
cons: non-supportive pro-staff that did not adequately help RAs through their issues. no work-life balance. Pro-staff claims your own personal life comes first; however, RAs were penalized if they did not put job first.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Highly motivated people, very supportive community, park-like setting, intellectually stimulating, and generally congenial attitudes.
cons: Assuming you have the job you are trained for it is a very enjoyable place to work.

review_title: Great work culture at ResNet but low pay
job_title: Resnet Technician in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Great work culture and a supporting team. Excellent management and team leads make the job very structured and organized. Free food is a plus.
cons: Low pay and very hectic first month. Wish the job payed more for the technical knowledge required to be good at the job.

job_title: Student Support Specialist in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: The campus is beautiful and being a student worker was great. Classes and coursework always came first and if work got in the way of that, it would be rectified.
cons: There was never a bump in compensation. It was hinted that after a year returning employees would receive a small pay raise but that never happened.

job_title: Game Designer/Programmer in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I learned how to work with a group and in a professional environment. The compensation was appropriate and had a lot of freedom on the project.
cons: It was hard to manage school and this job. It was difficult to understand exactly what the person who hired us wanted in the game, and how they wanted it to work.

job_title: Engineering Course Reader in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Since the job consists mostly of grading assignments, the majority of work is done at home. So, you can schedule when you will get your work done with a lot of freedom, making it easy to balance school work and extra curriculars.
cons: You may not always get the number of hours that you want.

job_title: in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
Beautiful campus. Walking through a forest to your classes and office is great. Student body is very friendly and the entire campus has a very relaxed feel.

Decent health/vision/dental insurance.
cons: Graduate students get paid crap, here and everywhere else. Relaxed atmosphere seeps into educational rigor, students are often unmotivated to excel and professors seem to have low expectations.

job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I have worked at UCSC as a postdoc for 5 years. I had a wonderful time, but that depended very much on my direct supervisors
cons: UC rules for postdocs are becoming quite strict (maximum 5 years of postdoc for instance). The office responsible for international students/scholars could better serve the foreigners.

review_title: My experience working at UC Santa Cruz has been very positive; I'd recommend it.
job_title: in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: It is a good place to work because it's a great environment, it has great staff/colleagues, there are lots of interesting projects going on on campus, and the benefits are good.
cons: My only con is that I'm a temporary employee (time-limited).

job_title: Grader/Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: I was paid appropriately for the work I did and I learned a lot about how to best teach others material I know.
cons: Before signing up to tutor, you had to set up a max amount of hours you were willing to work per week. It was not generally allowed to work beyond these hours.

review_title: I worked as a Graduate student researcher at UC santa cruz in summer, it was great
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA
pros: Not an intense work, I can WFH 2 or even 3 days a week. But I need to meet my professor every week so that he knows I am making progress.

job_title: Financial Analyst III in Santa Cruz, CA

job_title: Reader Tutor in Santa Cruz, CA

job_title: Assistant Professor in Santa Cruz, CA

review_title: Come for the research, stay for the environment
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Santa Cruz, CA

review_title: It's hard to make progress here.....

review_title: Fun but the change in menu meant less freshly prepared food and more pre-packaged stuff.

Great benefits

job_title: Mailroom Clerk in Santa Cruz, CA
